question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
Lack of required / vitamins and minerals / lead against / several complications / in the human body.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Correct Answer: lead against

Solution:
The phrase "lead against" is incorrect. The correct phrase should be "lead to", which means cause or result in.

Correct sentence:
Lack of required vitamins and minerals lead to several complications in the human body.

Meanings:
lead to ‚Äì cause or result in ‚Äì ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡§æ
lack ‚Äì absence or deficiency ‚Äì ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Ä
vitamins and minerals ‚Äì essential nutrients ‚Äì ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ü‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú
complications ‚Äì problems or difficulties ‚Äì ‡§ú‡§ü‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§è‡§Å

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) This fridge / (B) comes including / (C) a 5-year / (D) warranty.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
The part that contains an error is: (B) comes including

The phrase "comes with" is more idiomatic when talking about what is included with a product, such as a warranty.

The corrected sentence should be: "This fridge comes with a 5-year warranty."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The team dwelt with / their performance / in the last quarter.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: The team dwelt with

Explanation:

  • The correct verb-preposition combination is "dwell on" or "dwell upon" when talking about thinking or focusing on something.

  • "Dwelt with" is incorrect in this context.

  • Therefore, the error is in the segment "The team dwelt with".

Hence, The team dwelt with is the part containing the error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Guard over / making mistakes / by carefully checking / the assigned task.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 1
Solution: The error lies in the segment "Guard over".

The correct phrasal verb is "Guard against", not "Guard over".

  • "Guard against" means to take precautions to prevent something (‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§∞‡§§‡§®‡§æ / ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ).
    So, the correct sentence should be:
    "Guard against making mistakes by carefully checking the assigned task."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He entered the room / such quietly that / none of us / noticed him.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct construction is ‚Äúso quietly that‚Äù, not ‚Äúsuch quietly that.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúSo‚Äù modifies the adverb ‚Äúquietly‚Äù appropriately in a degree clause.

Thus, the error lies in the segment ‚Äúsuch quietly that.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Hard had she / thrown the basketball / when it fell / on the ground.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is:

Hard had she.

The correct structure should be "Hardly had she". The phrase "Hardly had she" is an inversion used to emphasize the action, indicating that something happened immediately after or in a very short time.

So, the corrected sentence would be:
"Hardly had she thrown the basketball when it fell on the ground."

question:
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
When it / come to football, / my brother is / an addict.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 4))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is "come to football,".

The phrase should be "comes to football," because the subject "it" is singular, and the verb should agree with the singular subject.

So, the correct sentence would be: "When it comes to football, my brother is an addict."

Thus, the answer is "come to football,".

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
I goes to / attend dance classes at / the National Dance Academy.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is "I goes to".

Explanation:

  • "I" is the subject, and the correct verb form should be "go" (not "goes") because "I" requires the base form of the verb in the present tense.

  • The corrected sentence should be: "I go to attend dance classes at the National Dance Academy."

Thus, the answer is "I goes to."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Since the little girl answers / a few simple questions, / her parents say that / she is too intelligent.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 3))
option_1: Since the little girl answers
solution:
ÔÇ∑ "She is too intelligent" suggests that the girl‚Äôs intelligence is excessive or beyond what is expected, possibly implying that her intelligence is a problem or causes an issue (perhaps it‚Äôs more than what is necessary for the situation).

ÔÇ∑ "She is very intelligent" simply states that the girl is highly intelligent without any suggestion of excess or problems.

So, error lies in option 3, ‚Äúvery‚Äù should be use instead of ‚Äútoo‚Äù.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Ramya is working / hardly / to get good marks.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 1))
solution:
The part that contains the error is "hardly."

Explanation:

  • The word "hardly" means "barely" or "scarcely," and it is used to indicate that something is done to a very small extent or with difficulty.

  • In this context, it contradicts the intended meaning. The sentence likely intends to say that Ramya is working hard to get good marks, meaning she is putting in a lot of effort.

  • The correct word should be "hard" instead of "hardly".

Corrected sentence:

"Ramya is working hard to get good marks."

Final Answer: hardly

question:
Identify the error in the given sentence and select the correct sentence from the given options.
Petrified wood is type of fossilised wood that exhibits the original details of the wood.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 1))
option_1: Petrified wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the original details of the wood.
option_2: A petrified wood is type of fossilised wood that exhibits an original details of the wood.
option_3: The petrified wood is the type of fossilised wood that exhibits a original details of the wood.
option_4: Petrified wood is the type of fossilised wood that exhibits a original details of the wood.
solution:
The correct sentence is:
"Petrified wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the original details of the wood."

Explanation:

  • The error in the original sentence is the lack of the article "a" before "type." The correct construction is "a type" because "type" is a singular countable noun.

  • The use of "the" before "wood" is unnecessary because it's already specified as "petrified wood," so "the" is not needed in this context.

Final Answer:

"Petrified wood is a type of fossilised wood that exhibits the original details of the wood."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Rashmi was / quite amusing when / she heard about / what had happened.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is "quite amusing when."

Explanation:

  • The phrase "quite amusing when" is awkward and incorrect because it implies that Rashmi was amusing when she heard about something. However, the intended meaning seems to be that Rashmi found the situation amusing, not that she was amusing herself.

  • The correct phrase should be "quite amused when" to indicate that Rashmi found the situation amusing.

Final Answer: quite amusing when

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She was singing beautifully/ in the concert hall / last night / No error.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 4))
solution:
Answer: 3 (No error)

Solution:

  • She was singing beautifully ‚Äî Correct use of past continuous tense with the adverb "beautifully."

  • in the concert hall ‚Äî Correct prepositional phrase indicating location.

  • last night ‚Äî Correct time expression.

  • There is no grammatical error in any segment of the sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error mark 'No error' as your answer.
The aeroplane took down / without the passengers after / making a sudden announcement.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:The aeroplane took down

Explanation:

The phrasal verb ‚Äútook down‚Äù is incorrect in this context.
The correct phrasal verb should be ‚Äútook off‚Äù, which means to leave the ground and begin flying (used for aircraft).

  • ‚ÄúTook down‚Äù means to bring something down (e.g., notes or decorations), not to refer to a plane departing.

‚úÖ Corrected sentence: ‚ÄúThe aeroplane took off without the passengers after making a sudden announcement.‚Äù

Part of speech corrected:
Verb (Phrasal Verb) ‚Äì "took down" is replaced by "took off" for correct aviation-related usage.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
She shall being / travelling / by this time / tomorrow.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (05-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer:She shall being

Explanation:

The phrase ‚Äúshall being‚Äù is grammatically incorrect.
The correct structure for expressing future continuous tense is:

üëâ ‚Äúshall be + verb-ing‚Äù

So, it should be: ‚ÄúShe shall be travelling‚Äù, not ‚Äúshall being‚Äù.

‚úÖ Corrected sentence: She shall be travelling by this time tomorrow.

Part of speech corrected:
Verb (auxiliary + main verb) ‚Äì ‚Äúbeing‚Äù is replaced with ‚Äúbe‚Äù to correctly form the future continuous tense.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
In geography class, / the teacher told the students, / "Switzerland lies / inside Germany, France, Austria, and Italy."

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 1))
option_3: the teacher told the students,
option_4: inside Germany, France, Austria, and Italy.
solution:
Correct Answer: inside Germany, France, Austria, and Italy.

Explanation:

The error lies in the phrase "Switzerland lies inside Germany, France, Austria, and Italy." The word "inside" is incorrect because Switzerland is not located inside those countries. Rather, it borders them or is surrounded by them.

  • The correct expression should be:
    "Switzerland lies between Germany, France, Austria, and Italy."
    or
    "Switzerland is bordered by Germany, France, Austria, and Italy."

Hence, the grammatical/logical error is in the phrase "inside Germany, France, Austria, and Italy."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
There was an gang of thieves spotted at our local bank, make sure to be careful.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (09-July Shift 4))
option_4: make sure to be careful
solution:
Correct Answer: There was an gang

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "an gang".
The article "an" is used before words that begin with a vowel sound, but "gang" starts with a consonant sound.
So, it should be "a gang", not "an gang".

Part of Speech (Corrected Part):
"Gang" ‚Äì Noun
"A" ‚Äì Article (Determiner)
Correction: There was a gang of thieves...

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
After your insistence, / my sister / checked / a mailbox again.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 2))
solution:
Correct Answer: a mailbox again.

Part of Speech of Corrected Part:

  • a mailbox ‚Üí should be the mailbox (article correction)

Explanation:
The sentence refers to a specific mailbox, so the definite article "the" should be used instead of the indefinite article "a."

Correct sentence:
"After your insistence, my sister checked the mailbox again."

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"a mailbox again."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The manager noticed / that Pragya / was first to reach / the office on Saturday.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: was first to reach

Explanation:
The phrase "was first to reach" is missing the article "the" before "first." The correct form should be:
"was the first to reach" ‚Äî indicating Pragya was the earliest to arrive.

Corrected sentence:
"The manager noticed that Pragya was the first to reach the office on Saturday."

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"was first to reach."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The chief guest gave out prizes to the meritorious students of the school.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (10-July Shift 4))
solution:
Correct Answer: gave out prizes

Explanation:
The phrase "gave out prizes" is often considered informal or less appropriate in formal writing. The preferred phrase is "distributed prizes" or simply "gave prizes."

However, grammatically, "gave out" is not incorrect but stylistically less formal. Since the question asks for an error, the most likely intended answer is this phrase for style or formality reasons.

The other parts:

  • The chief guest ‚Äì Correct

  • to the meritorious students ‚Äì Correct

  • of the school ‚Äì Correct

So, the segment containing the error or inappropriate usage is:
"gave out prizes."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
She was fond of walking along the path besides the lake.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 1))
solution:
Correct Answer: besides the lake

Explanation:
The preposition "besides" means in addition to or apart from, which is incorrect in this context.

The correct preposition here is "beside", meaning next to or alongside.

Correct phrase:
"along the path beside the lake."

So, the segment with the error is:
"besides the lake."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My Vice-Chancellor works / eighteen hours / a day, / seven days week.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (11-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: seven days week.

Part of Speech of Corrected Part:

  • seven days a week (noun phrase with article "a" indicating frequency)

Explanation:
The correct expression is "seven days a week", meaning every day in the week.

Correct sentence:
"My Vice-Chancellor works eighteen hours a day, seven days a week."

So, the segment with the grammatical error is:
"seven days week."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
My sister-in-law is the most succeeded for all the industrialists in this country today.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.10_08-Oct_Shift-2)
option_4: My sister-in-law is the most
solution:
Correct answer: succeeded for all

Explanation:

  • The phrase "succeeded for all" is incorrect.

  • The correct expression is "successful among" or "the most successful" instead of "the most succeeded."

  • "Succeeded" is a verb, while the sentence requires an adjective "successful" to describe the sister-in-law.

Correct version:
"My sister-in-law is the most successful among all the industrialists in this country today."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
While she / was watched / the movie, / her phone rang.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.10_08-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer: was watched

Explanation:

  • The phrase "was watched" is incorrect because it wrongly uses the passive voice.

  • The sentence requires the past continuous active voice: "was watching."

  • Correct segment: "was watching"

Correct sentence:
"While she was watching the movie, her phone rang."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A famous economist / says that / the government should do more / for create enough jobs.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.13_09-Oct_Shift-2)
option_4: the government should do more
solution:
Correct answer: for create enough jobs

Explanation:

  • The phrase "for create enough jobs" is grammatically incorrect.

  • The correct phrase should be "to create enough jobs" because after "do more," the infinitive form "to create" is used.

  • Other parts of the sentence are correct.

Correct sentence:
"A famous economist says that the government should do more to create enough jobs."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
The table looks pÃ≤rÃ≤oÃ≤pÃ≤eÃ≤rÃ≤ in the centre than in the corner.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.16_14-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: more proper

Explanation:

  • The adjective "proper" has more than one syllable, so when making a comparison, we use "more" instead of adding "-er".

  • The sentence is making a comparative statement: comparing the table's position in the centre vs. in the corner.

  • ‚úÖ Correct form: "more proper"

Let‚Äôs eliminate the incorrect options:

  • most proper ‚Äì superlative; used when comparing more than two things.

  • properer ‚Äì incorrect; "proper" doesn't take "-er" for comparison.

  • properly ‚Äì an adverb, not suitable here as we're comparing adjective usage (the table‚Äôs position, not how it was placed).

So, the corrected sentence is:
"The table looks more proper in the centre than in the corner."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
All in all, he had the mÃ≤oÃ≤rÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤sÃ≤pÃ≤lÃ≤eÃ≤nÃ≤dÃ≤iÃ≤dÃ≤ collection of antique paintings ever.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.2_30-Sep_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer:
most splendid

Explanation:
The word "splendid" is an adjective. When forming the superlative degree of adjectives with three or more syllables, we use "most" + adjective. Hence, "most splendid" is correct instead of incorrect forms like "splendidest" or "more splendider."

Part of speech corrected:
Adjective (superlative degree)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Chetan's room is clean / than Ram's room because / Chetan cleans it more often than Ram.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
option_4: Chetan cleans it more often than Ram
solution:
Correct Answer: Chetan's room is clean

Explanation:

The error is in the first segment "Chetan's room is clean". When comparing two things‚ÄîChetan's room and Ram's room‚Äîwe should use the comparative form of the adjective "clean", which is "cleaner".

  • The correct sentence is:
    "Chetan's room is cleaner than Ram's room because Chetan cleans it more often than Ram."

Using just "clean" makes the comparison grammatically incorrect. The sentence structure demands a comparative adjective because of the word "than" following it.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There has been / an increase of the number / of road / accidents recently.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.22_16-Oct_Shift-2)
option_3: an increase of the number
solution:
Answer: an increase of the number

Explanation:
The phrase "an increase of the number" is grammatically incorrect. The correct phrase should be:

  • "an increase in the number"

The correct preposition after "increase" when referring to quantity, number, or amount is usually "in", not "of".

Correct sentence:
"There has been an increase in the number of road accidents recently."

So, the error is in the segment: "an increase of the number".

question:
The given sentence is divided into four segments. Select the option that has the segment with the grammatical error.
Mahesh and his workers / will have been worked / on the project / for a long time.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.3_30-Sep_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer:will have been worked

Explanation:

The phrase "will have been worked" is grammatically incorrect.
It uses the wrong verb form in the future perfect continuous tense.

Let‚Äôs break it down:

  • The correct structure for future perfect continuous tense is:
    will have been + present participle (verb+ing)
    Example: "They will have been working on the project for months."

  • "Worked" is the past participle, but we need the present participle "working" here.

Correct form: "will have been working"

So, the sentence should be:
"Mahesh and his workers will have been working on the project for a long time."

Therefore, the segment "will have been worked" contains the grammatical error.

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 2))
option_1: Ragini plays the guitar with a melody.
option_2: Ragini plays the guitar melodiously.
option_3: Ragini plays the guitar with melodiousness.
option_4: Ragini plays the guitar melodious.
solution:
Answer: 2 (Ragini plays the guitar melodiously.)

Explanation:

  • "Melodiously" is an adverb correctly describing how Ragini plays the guitar.

  • The other options are grammatically incorrect or awkward in usage.

Therefore, the correct sentence is:
Ragini plays the guitar melodiously.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
It is eÃ≤aÃ≤sÃ≤iÃ≤eÃ≤sÃ≤tÃ≤ to stay calm than to protest.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.32_21-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: easier

Explanation:

  • When comparing two things, the correct comparative form is "easier", not "easiest."

  • "Easiest" is the superlative form used when comparing more than two things.

  • Other options:

  • easy is the base form, not comparative.

  • the easier is incorrect without a clear comparison or context.

  • more easier is incorrect because "easier" already implies comparison.

Correct sentence:
"It is easier to stay calm than to protest."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
‚ÄãThey was / celebrating their / Silver wedding anniversary / next month in Dubai.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.34_22-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:They was

Explanation:
The subject "They" is plural, so it must be followed by the plural verb "were", not "was".
Correct usage: They were celebrating...

Correct Sentence:
They were celebrating their Silver wedding anniversary next month in Dubai.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
It was an interesting chat with an European gymnast that changed my mindset towards the sport.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.38_23-Oct_Shift-3)
option_3: my mindset towards the sport
option_4: an European gymnast that changed
solution:
Answer:an European gymnast that changed

Explanation:
The error lies in the use of the article "an" before "European."

Although "European" begins with a vowel letter (E), it starts with a /y/ sound (like "you-ro-pean"), which is a consonant sound. Therefore, the correct article is "a", not "an".

Correct phrase:
a European gymnast

Correct sentence:
It was an interesting chat with a European gymnast that changed my mindset towards the sport.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
Ahuja is a cÃ≤lÃ≤eÃ≤vÃ≤eÃ≤rÃ≤eÃ≤sÃ≤tÃ≤ lawyer.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.39_28-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:clever

Explanation:
The original sentence is:
"Ahuja is a cleverest lawyer."

This is grammatically incorrect because the article "a" should not be used before a superlative adjective like "cleverest". Superlative adjectives require "the" (e.g., the cleverest lawyer).

Since the sentence uses "a", we need to use the positive degree of the adjective, which is "clever" ‚Äì ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞ / ‡§π‡•ã‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞.

Let‚Äôs evaluate the options:

  • cleverer ‚Äì comparative form, used when comparing two people ‚Äì ‚ùå

  • clever ‚Äì base form; fits correctly after "a" ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • more clever ‚Äì awkward and less common ‚Äì ‚ùå

  • most clever ‚Äì superlative form; should be used with "the" ‚Äì ‚ùå

Correct sentence:
Ahuja is a clever lawyer.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The society / of the / our place / is good.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.4_01-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer:of the

Explanation:

The sentence is: "The society / of the / our place / is good."

The segment "of the our place" is grammatically incorrect because two determiners ("the" and "our") cannot be used together before a noun.

Correct usage:

  • Use either "the" or "our", not both.

  • The correct phrase should be: "of our place"

Correct sentence:
"The society of our place is good."

Therefore, the segment "of the" contains the grammatical error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The soldiers / sacrifice their lives / to guarding / the nation and its boundaries.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.43_29-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: the nation and its boundaries
solution:
Answer:to guarding

Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "to guarding".

The correct structure after "sacrifice their lives" is:
"sacrifice their lives to guard..." (i.e., base form of the verb, not gerund)

  • "to" here is a preposition that should be followed by the base verb (guard), not verb+ing (guarding).

Correct sentence:
The soldiers sacrifice their lives to guard the nation and its boundaries.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
Wolfia is the tÃ≤iÃ≤nÃ≤yÃ≤ plant in the world.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.46_30-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: tiniest

Explanation:
The sentence is referring to one plant being the smallest in the entire world, so we need the superlative degree of the adjective.

tiny ‚Üí positive (‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ)
tinier ‚Üí comparative (‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ)
tiniest ‚Üí superlative (‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ)

The correct form is tiniest because it's comparing all plants in the world.

Corrected sentence: Wolfia is the tiniest plant in the world.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The company decided / to phase up its / outdated technology / and embrace innovation.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.47_30-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: d) to phase up its

Explanation:
The phrasal verb "phase up" is incorrect in this context.
The correct phrasal verb is "phase out", which means to gradually stop using or remove something (‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á-‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ).

  • The sentence talks about removing outdated technology, so the correct verb is "phase out", not "phase up".

Correct sentence: "The company decided to phase out its outdated technology and embrace innovation."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
This is one of best movies I have ever seen.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.48_04-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: a) one of best

Explanation:
The correct phrase should be: "one of the best", not "one of best".

  • When using the structure "one of...", it must be followed by "the + superlative adjective + plural noun"
     e.g., one of the best movies, one of the greatest players

So, the corrected sentence is: "This is one of the best movies I have ever seen."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Much of the beauty and glory of life have disappeared.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.48_04-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: a) have disappeared.

Explanation:
The subject "Much of the beauty and glory of life" is singular, because it refers to a single combined idea (the overall splendour of life).

  • So, the verb should be "has disappeared", not "have disappeared".

Correct sentence:
"Much of the beauty and glory of life has disappeared."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Before the internet was available on mobile, I read often books for entertainment and information.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.50_04-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: a) I read often books

Explanation:
The phrase "I read often books" is grammatically incorrect due to word order.

  • The correct structure in English is: Adverb (often) comes before the main verb or after the object, not between verb and object.

Correct sentence:
"I often read books for entertainment and information."

Corrected word order:
Subject + adverb + verb + object

So, the error is in "I read often books" ‚Üí it should be "I often read books."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She speaks / so soft that / hardly anyone / can hear her.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.58_12-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: a) so soft that

Explanation:
The phrase should be "so softly that" because "soft" is an adjective, but here an adverb is needed to describe how she speaks.

  • Softly = adverb form of soft (‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•á)
    Correct sentence: "She speaks so softly that hardly anyone can hear her."
    Other parts are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
(1) We knocked across (2) early on Saturday (3) to enjoy (4) the beautiful weather.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.62_13-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: We knocked across

Explanation:
The phrase "knocked across" is incorrect here.
The correct phrase should be "knocked on" (‡§¶‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§º‡§æ ‡§ñ‡§ü‡§ñ‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§æ) or "went across" depending on the context.
"Knocked across" is not a valid phrasal verb in this context.

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Please hang with for two minutes while I finish cleaning the utensils.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.62_13-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: Please hang with

Explanation:
The phrase "Please hang with" is incorrect.
The correct phrase should be "Please hang on", which means to wait briefly (‡§•‡•ã‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§á‡§Ç‡§§‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç).
Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
Select the option that has an error in the use of phrasal verb.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.7_07-Oct_Shift-2)
option_1: Back up your essential files. Technology is only sometimes reliable.
option_2: Please turn up the heater. The weather is too cold today .
option_3: Pushpa came across an old photo in the album and asked me to recognise the face in it.
option_4: Please suggest me some tips to get out nervousness.
solution:
Correct answer: Please suggest me some tips to get out nervousness.

Explanation:

  • The phrasal verb "get out" means to leave a place or escape, and it does not collocate with abstract feelings like nervousness.

  • The correct expression should be "get over nervousness" or "overcome nervousness", which means to successfully deal with or recover from it.

  • Also, "suggest me" is grammatically incorrect because "suggest" is not followed by an indirect object. You should say:

  • ‚úÖ "Please suggest some tips to me" or

  • ‚úÖ "Please suggest how I can overcome nervousness."

So, both the phrasal verb and verb usage are incorrect in the sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains anerror in phrasal verb.
Tara was late for the meeting / but somehow managed / to catch out with / everything she had missed.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.9_08-Oct_Shift-1)
option_2: Tara was late for the meeting
solution:
Correct answer: to catch out with

Explanation:

  • The correct phrasal verb is "catch up with," meaning to reach the same point or level as others.

  • "Catch out with" is incorrect and does not convey the intended meaning.

Correct sentence:
"Tara was late for the meeting but somehow managed to catch up with everything she had missed."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The police could not / hold on the people / for long as they / gathered in large numbers

(SSC CHSL 2022 T-2 (26 June 2023))
solution:
Solution: Option d is the correct answer.

The given sentence is grammatically incorrect. To rectify the sentence we will use ‚ÄòHold Up‚Äô instead of ‚ÄòHold on‚Äô.

The correct sentence is: The police could not hold up the people for long as they gathered in large numbers.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The Supreme Court set away / the verdict of the High Court / and agreed to hear the plea / of the complainant.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-2)
option_1: The Supreme Court set away
option_2: and agreed to hear the plea
option_4: the verdict of the High Court
solution: The phrase "set away" is incorrect in this context. The correct expression should be "set aside", which means to annul, cancel, or disregard a decision or judgment.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
The committee requested / the Chief Investigator / to personally / look after the matter.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (2 Nov))
solution:
The segment that contains an error is: look after the matter

Look into should come in place of Look after.

Look into: to investigate, analyze, or study a situation

Look after:take care of someone or something.
